A <math alttext="3 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-long conductor carries a current of <math alttext="200 amperes"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> toward the right. Point <math alttext="P"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is located a short distance off the wire, as shown. (a) Use the Biot-Savart law to calculate the magnetic field due to the wire at point <math alttext="P"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) An electron reaches point <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> moving parallel to the wire and to the right with speed <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> . i. On the axes below, sketch a graph of the magnitude of acceleration <math alttext="a"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of speed <math alttext="v"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the electron as it passes point <math alttext="P"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>P</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. In the space below, draw a vector to represent the direction of the acceleration of the electron. A circle with a dot should be used to represent the <math alttext="positive z"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction, and a circle with an "<math alttext="X"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>" should be used to represent the <math alttext="negative z"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction. Justify your answer.

Students perform an experiment to determine a value for the vacuum permeability constant <math alttext="mu sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. A second conductor is added a distance <math alttext="d equals 10 centimeters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> away from the first conductor. The conductors are parallel to each other, and each has a current <math alttext="I"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown. A force probe is used to measure the magnitude of the force the conductors exert on each other. For several trials, the students increase the value of <math alttext="I"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and record the force per unit length <math alttext="the fraction F over l"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ℓ</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for the conductors. Vertical axis: ____________ Horizontal axis: ____________ Use the remaining rows in the table above, as needed, to record any quantities that you indicated that are not given in the table. Label each column you use and include units.

(d) i. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part <math alttext="c"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>c</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on the graph below. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units if appropriate. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.
ii. Using the straight line, calculate an experimental value for <math alttext="mu sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.
